notes.notes: finally shooting up new stalks. the drosera binata that snuck into the pot have been doing much more famously than the primary tenant. I'm very excited to see that a drosera binata var. multifida is in the pot as well!

taxon: Sarracenia rubra ssp. gulfensis 'ancestral x giant'

notes.notes: finally shot up a quickly growing pitcher! about 4 inches so far. all of the Sarracenia, plus the single Darlingtonia have been moved to their own tray, and packed with New Zealand sphagnum in the extra space. I am going to fashion an automatic watering bottle to keep these guys always happy and moist.
gave away during the christmas party.
doing great
doing well enough, but comparitively not as excellent as the alba.
medium size. Super dark purple pitchers, almost black.
notes.source: Bought on site at California Carnivores.
Bought on site at California Carnivores.

notes.notes: the primary plant as well as the babies are flourishing. they have developed a beautiful red tinge, probably due to the long light I am giving every day. almost slobbering with dew.
looking great, about to flower. I installed a timer for my lights and the deep red seems to have died down.
still looking great. completely slobbery. flowering with cute little red starbursts.

notes.source: Bought on site at California Carnivores.

notes.notes: the primary plant as well as the babies are flourishing. they have developed a beautiful red tinge, probably due to the long light I am giving every day. almost slobbering with dew.
same as the other Adelae, both are shooting up stalks to flower, and a couple of the smaller plants as well.
same as the other adelae. doing great.

notes.source: Bought on site at California Carnivores.

notes.notes: slack potted in terra cotta clay pot, with mix made by Peter D'Amato. pot is approximately 6" bottom diameter and 9.5" on top. height is approx. 9". some sphagnum over bottom hole to block losing soil. trimmed dead stalks away. thorougly wetted with distilled water. didn't have enough mix to fill to top, will have to add more soon.

been largely kept inside to shelter from the cold. put outside if the regular rains dont seem to be coming and sunny out. I think the lessened light has caused there to be less dew and shorter leaves. when bought, it was absolutely slobbering. now is looks less than the adelae, and maybe equivalent to the capensis dew-wise.
was left outside in the rain and cold one night, maybe a week ago, seems to be slowly dying.
'Peter' the Drosophyllum passed away a good bit ago, but I was too depressed to log it.

notes.source: Bought on site at California Carnivores.

notes.notes: have not seen any great growth, but there are definitely small green pitcher-letts. Put up a greenhouse this week, planning on moving outside, as well as the other Sarracenia, if I can ensure the greenhouse is keeping within a good temperature and humidity range.

notes.source: Bought on site at California Carnivores.

notes.notes: Alive, and looks okay, but have not seen any notable growth. Flightless drosophila eggs and media arrived this week, they've since grown into many larvae, hoping they turn into fruit flies soon to try to coax this plant into more growth.

notes.source: Bought on site at California Carnivores.

notes.notes: Doing super well, there's a couple extra pups. The biggest two plants have flowered and are very pretty! I haven't looked up the polination yet, but tried to angle the flowers over the cyclosecta pot in case anything falls.
The pups have flowered as well. I didn't have any toothpicks, so I attempted to cross-polinate with q-tips. I don't think it worked at all.
My friend from the coffeeshop gave me some toothpicks, so I tried again to polinate the flowers.

notes.source: Bought on site at California Carnivores.

notes.notes: Still so tiny!!! Unsure if giving best environment.

I realize now that this plant was in its winter rosette form, I started paying a bit more attention to the watering and two bigger leaves formed almost right away. I am hoping it is transforming into the carnivorous phase.

notes.source: Bought on site at California Carnivores.

notes.notes: Doing a-okay, has made a couple more pitchers.

notes.source: Bought on site at California Carnivores.

notes.notes: went home with Fonda

notes.source: Bought on site at California Carnivores.

notes.notes: Alive, but pretty tiny still, a whole new pitcher grew.
Gave approximately a third of an osmocote in the newest pitcher that had relatively recently opened.
The osmocote was too much! The pitcher is instantly withered.

taxon: Sarracenia. flava v. cuprea 'BH' x v. ornata 'Bulloch Co, GA'
Sarracenia flava 'orange flower' x purpurea ssp. purpurea

notes.source: Bought on Amazon with work competition prize money.

notes.notes: gave to Annie

notes.source: This was originally bought from FOTGH at SFSU in 2015. Has been in Fonda's care.
Brian Lipinski at BACPS meeting, Oakland.

notes.comments: has a flower stalk growing. noticed a bunch of aphids on the stalk. have to do something about that. healthy looking otherwise.

notes.source: Amazon vendor. Hasnt responded to species questions.
Bought an unknown Nepenthes from Katsura Bonsai in Japantown.
notes.notes: Medium sized. Atm the largest in the collection. Many pitchers. All have started wilting, but will bring back to health.
Based on the bottom half of all the pitchers (the peristome and lid are withered on all) and general shape, I'm going to guess that this is a N. Alata or the hybrid N. Ventrata (alata x ventricosa).

Started repotting, and found out this recently bought plant was two! this company based on the label, looks like it is the same I got my next-most recently bought plant from 6th Avenue Aquarium. Now that I'm looking at the plant below the soil (milled peat), it looks like they directly sell cuttings in peat-pucks and drop them in more peat on selling. There was no root structure yet. I went ahead with repotting since I was this far along and gave a mostly sphagnum mix with perlite. I dipped the resuscitated sphagnum in perlite with each handful and then gently packed the plants in larger pots. Hope they survive! I wound up choosing this loose mix based on the Savage Garden's Nepenthes soil section. The other plant at this same arrival date is the other plant in the original pot. Bumped plant ID of other recent plant from NEPEN_16_2 to NEPEN_16_3.

notes.source: See notes on plant of same day. Bought both at Katsura Bonsai in Japantown.
Bought an unknown Nepenthes from 6th Avenue Aquarium. This is now the largest in my collection. Guessing a N. Alata.

notes.notes: I hope it isn't the case, but the Nepenthes I repotted today that appeared to be from the same company based on the plant tag were mostly just a peat puck in peat, with no root structure.. It is likely this is the same.
Seeds arrived a few days ago from ICPS seed bank. Labeled 'Warm Temperate'. Sprinkled seeds on top of a 50:50 peat:sand mix.

Seeds arrived a few days ago from ICPS seed bank. Labeled 'red/heavy veined, Cold Stratify 4 weeks, Do not plant on Federal property'. I should probably come up with another naming system for seeds. Sprinkled seeds on top of well chopped sphagnum. The sphagnum is a new species from a very generous Redditor. some sections of the sphagnum are red and purple. some is typical bright green too. Placed in a bag in the fridge for cold stratification.

notes.comments: Seeds arrived a few days ago from ICPS seed bank. Labeled 'Wisconson, Cold Stratify 4 Weeks'.

notes.notes: Seeds arrived a few days ago from ICPS seed bank. Labeled 'Pilliga Red, Summer Annual'. Sprinkled seeds on top of a 30% peat to 70% sand mix.
Seeds arrived a few days ago from ICPS seed bank. Labeled 'Pink Flower, (was indica)'. Sprinkled seeds on top of a 95% sand to 5% peat mix.

arrived a couple days ago, but gave a proper setup today. A generous Redditor sent it to us. Some sections are rather red or purple. a lot is the typical bright green. gave a base of pure peat in a tray. not really sure how much it matters, but tried to detect the parts that were "the bottom" and sowed further down in the peat. maybe a bit more than a half inch layer of peat.

sowed ~100 seeds in 5 small plastic pots. worried about short utric shelf life we read about. soil media was 2:1 peat to sand mix. sand was grade #12. put each container in a sandwich bag, but didn't zip all the way closed. put a bit of distilled water in each bag. placed directly under a light.
I'm giving up on these guys. I don't believe they're going to sprout. All the seeds have turned green, possibly algae.
